NewsLine.NewsLineText: AFRICA-HIGHLIGHTS 1000 GMT:Reuters Africa Highlights 1000 GMT Sept 23

body.p: BOUAKE, Ivory Coast - French troops rumbled north to evacuate Westerners trapped by fighting in Ivory Coast as skirmishes flared on the outskirts of a city where dozens of American children are hiding.

Rebel soldiers said they had beaten off a heavy attack on the city of Bouake by loyalist troops sent to crush an uprising that has plunged the West African country into its worst crisis since independence from France in 1960.
WASHINGTON - The United States urged American citizens to avoid travel to the West African nation of Ivory Coast because of continuing political violence.
ABUJA - A special Commonwealth committee is expected to weigh the possibility of tougher sanctions against Zimbabwe at a meeting snubbed by the country's President Robert Mugabe.
Nigeria, which is hosting the talks, said Mugabe had decided at the last minute to boycott the meeting, complaining of being made to feel "he was going to be court-martialled in Abuja".
CANBERRA - Australia condemned Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe's boycott of the meeting on his nation's land and political crisis and said it showed his indifference to world opinion.
HARARE - Zimbabwe launched a blistering attack on Australian Prime Minister John Howard, accusing him of racism and treating Africans in the same way Australia treats its Aborigines.

Government ministers defended President Robert Mugabe's snub of a special Commonwealth meeting in Nigeria on Monday where the leaders of Australia, Nigeria and South Africa were expected to weigh tougher sanctions against Zimbabwe.
KANO, Nigeria - Gunmen shot dead an outspoken opposition leader in Nigeria, where political assassinations have been on the rise as elections near.
The unknown assailants burst into the home of Isiaku Mohammed, vice-chairman of the new United Nigerian Peoples' Party, dragged him from his bed and shot him in the forehead.

KIGALI - French Foreign Minister Dominique de Villepin said the start of a Rwandan army withdrawal had revived Congo's peace prospects and he would now talk to Kinshasa about fulfilling its side of a peace deal.

"There is a new prospect of peace following the withdrawal of Rwandan forces," de Villepin, who is on a one-day tour of Africa's Great Lakes region, told reporters after talks with Rwandan President Paul Kagame.
